docs.lead_paragraph: The Red Sox had been repeatedly humiliated by their chief rival this year, but the Yankees committed four errors on Saturday night as Boston split their doubleheader with a win in game 2.
docs.abstract: New York Yankees and the Boston Red Sox split their doubleheader with the Yankees winning the first game, 6-1, and the Red Sox taking the second, 9-5.
docs.snippet: The Red Sox had been repeatedly humiliated by their chief rival this year, but the Yankees committed four errors on Saturday night as Boston split their doubleheader with a win in game 2....

docs.lead_paragraph: Thanks to Jon Lester’s pitching and David Ortiz’s hitting, the Red Sox are one victory away from winning the World Series after beating the Cardinals in Game 5.
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox beat St Louis Cardinals, 3-1, and are now one win from their eighth World Series championship; Jon Lester pitched a magnificent game for the second time in the Series; David Ortiz continues his remarkable run of success at the plate.
docs.snippet: Thanks to Jon Lester’s pitching and David Ortiz’s hitting, the Red Sox are one victory away from winning the World Series after beating the Cardinals in Game 5....

headline.main: One Win Away and Headed for Home
headline.print_headline: One Win Away and Headed for Home

docs.lead_paragraph: A little late-season magic helped both Boston and Tampa Bay, and they enter the final day of the regular season tied for the A.L. wild card.
docs.abstract: Harvey Araton On Baseball column on Boston Red Sox, who enter final day of regular season tied with Tampa Bay Rays for American League wild card; says Red Sox manager Terry Francona, whose future with club remains uncertain, is long way from breathing easy.
docs.snippet: A little late-season magic helped both Boston and Tampa Bay, and they enter the final day of the regular season tied for the A.L. wild card....

headline.print_headline: A Fight to the Finish: Lightning Strikes, And Francona Can Exhale

docs.lead_paragraph: Boston scored three in the third inning and three in the fourth to defeat St. Louis and win the series in six games, celebrating its first championship at Fenway Park since 1918.
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox win World Series after defeating the St Louis Cardinals, 6-1, in Game 6; Sox slugger David Ortiz, who scored two home runs in series, is awarded most valuable player; victory is franchise's third World Series win in past decade, their eighth overall and first at Fenway Park since 1918.
docs.snippet: Boston scored three in the third inning and three in the fourth to defeat St. Louis and win the series in six games, celebrating its first championship at Fenway Park since 1918....

headline.main: Red Sox Rout Cardinals to Win World Series

docs.lead_paragraph: Behind the pitching of Jon Lester, who struck out eight batters over seven and two-thirds scoreless innings, and an early 5-0 lead, Boston beat St. Louis in Game 1 of the World Series.
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox beat St Louis Cardinals, 8-1, in Game 1 of World Series; Red Sox capitalize on five runs in first two innings and several defensive miscues by the Cardinals.
docs.snippet: Behind the pitching of Jon Lester, who struck out eight batters over seven and two-thirds scoreless innings, and an early 5-0 lead, Boston beat St. Louis in Game 1 of the World Series....

docs.lead_paragraph: Bronson Arroyo knew that he was being removed from the game in the fourth inning after a woeful performance. But Arroyo still slid his right foot across the pitcher's rubber several times to tidy up the area he was vacating. It was the least he could do. Because Arroyo had made such a mess with his wayward pitches Wednesday night, he tried to reduce the mess that was left on the rubber. There was nothing Arroyo could do about the clutter left on the scoreboard, the ugly numbers that explained how the Toronto Blue Jays were whipping the Boston Red Sox.
docs.snippet: Bronson Arroyo allowed three homers in the first three innings and helped turn Fenway Park into a library....

docs.lead_paragraph: The wonderful world of the Mets, a happy and heady place in baseball all year, crumbled a bit more last night before 55,063 wondering fans in Shea Stadium. The Boston Red Sox pummeled Dwight Gooden and three other pitchers for 18 hits, swatted out a 9-3 victory and beat the Mets for the second straight time in the 83d World Series. And the Red Sox did it even though the great pitching match between Gooden and Roger Clemens did not reach the sixth inning. So, having lost two games at home, the Mets faced the grim prospect of trying to revive in Fenway Park, where the Series will be resumed tomorrow night with Bob Ojeda pitching against Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd of the Red Sox. Both teams won sizzling playoffs for their league pennants, but the effort seemed to have drained the Mets more than it did the Red Sox, who came into the Series as sizable underdogs. The Red Sox have held the Mets to 12 hits in two nights, all singles, and have shut down the team that fashioned the best record in baseball in 1986.
